occurrences.line_text: And ye faire Ladies, that your kingdomes make
That was as trew in loue, as Turtle to her make.
Threatning into his life to make a breach,
Hath outrag'd you, and thrald your gentle make.
So forth they both yfere make their progresse,
Gainst all the Gods, to make his empire great;
But faire Alcmena better match did make,
Ne ought but deare Bisaltis ay could make him glad.
That all his many it affraide did make:
And all perforce to make her him to loue.
Yet all that did not her dismaied make,
Shall through the world make to be notifyde,
In stead thereof know, that your louing Make,
Yet could she not but curteous cou[n]tenance to her make.
That one did make, the other mard againe,
His siluer Harpe in hand, and shortly friends them make.
So fayre a spoyle, to make you ioyous meriment?
And gan this bitter answere to him make;
And of your gotten spoyle their owne triumph to make.
And each not farre behinde him had his make,
That twixt themselues did gentle purpose make
(The harder it to make them well agree)
That of them all, which loue to her did make,
More wise they weend to make of loue delight,
And cruell battell twixt themselues doe make,
To make an end of all that did withstand:
But this doth hatred make in loue to brenne,
As was his wont; so weening way to make
That all the rest it did amazed make,
And make his praise before his owne preferd:
And squiers make hast to helpe their Lords fordonne.
This pretious ornament they say did make,
Thereby to make their loues beginning, their liues end.
Yet durst he not make loue so suddenly,
And loth to leaue her late betrothed make,
Which she forgot, whereby excuse to make:
And humble homage did vnto him make,
Ne ought mote make him change his wonted tenor,
Yet saw her forward still to make her flight,
And gan to her her mournfull plaint to make,
Or selfe disliked life doth thee thus wretched make?
And make me loath this life, still longing for to die.
And each vnto his lust did make a lawe,
Was spoyle to make, and wast them vnto nought,
And after promist large amends to make.
Thereto he offred for to make him chiefe
But Paridell of loue did make no threasure,
He ment to make them know their follies prise,
Phidias did make in Paphos Isle of yore,
Of that faire City, wherein make abode
And Mole, that like a nousling Mole doth make
Then gan he make him tread his steps anew,
And so doe make contrarie constitution
She caused him to make experience
Which steely brand, to make him dreaded more,
Aread (sayd he) which way then did he make?
But thitherward forthright his ready way did make.
Might otherwise preuaile, or make him cease for ought.
So would he of the fire one ballaunce make,
And make them leuell with the lowly plaine:
Tyrants that make men subiect to their law,
Does make her selfe misfortunes piteous pray.
Together met, of all to make an end.
With proud disdaine did scornefull answere make;
Of both their beauties to make paragone,
Whereof to make due tryall, one did take
Sir Terpine, haplesse man, what make you here?
And to them way to make, with weapons well prepard.
And shew'd, that with his Lord she would emparlaunce make.
And of her seruant make her souerayne Lord:
Thereof make tryall, in my greatest need:
And to his fortunes helpe make readie way?
Make meanes to win thy libertie forlorne,
And of his innocence to make her pray.
She told but moneths, to make them seeme more few:
As if that by his silence he would make
There she began to make her monefull plaint
She saw it vaine to make there lenger stay,
Thorough the midst of them she way did make.
To make new warre against the Gods againe:
Yet when she saw the heapes, which he did make,
To captiue men, and make them all the world reiect.
Yet mote he algates now abide, and answere make.
They drew their swords, in mind to make amends
But lastly to make proofe of vtmost shame,
To their deseigne to make the easier way,
Seeking by euery way to make some breach,
There he him courst a fresh, and soone did make
Those two strange knights such homage to her make,
And with him to make part against her, came
Yet glad at last to make most base submission,
Whereto she euer list to make her hardy flight.
That any man would nigh awhaped make.
Willd him to stay, and signe of truce did make:
Or harme, that any had, then would she make
She would it eeke, and make much worse by telling,
How they might make him into mischiefe fall,
That they the mildest man aliue would make
And more to make the[m] pierce & wound more deepe,
Doth vanquish Crudor, and doth make
That shall you most renowmed make for euermore.
And seeing him so fiercely towardes make,
And wicked customes make, those doe defame
And tryde all waies, how each mote entrance make
His Helme, to make vnto his vengeance way.
What cause could make him so dishonourable,
That ye will make me Squire without delay,
To make abode that night he greatly was besought.
And make their welcome to them well appeare:
His meanesse much, & make her th'others riches scorne.
To make them both as merry as he may.
He there did make, and then most carefully
To make a garland to adorne her hed,
Loe I defie thee, and here challenge make,
To make there lenger stay, forth on his iourney goth.
That meant to make aduantage of his misery.
Of his sore vengeaunce, or to make auoure
Did vnderneath them make a gloomy shade;
For all her paine, if please her make the priefe.
To make them to endure the pains, did them torment.
Would not permit, to make their lenger stay,
Make th'heauens tremble oft, & him with vowes asswage.
To moue one foote, but there must make abode;
Where so he went, but after him did make.
To some hid end to make more easie way,
Betwixt them to diuide, and each to make his owne.
In which they mote make triall of their might,
As when a cast of Faulcons make their flight
Therefore now yeeld, as ye did promise make,
That such proud looks would make her praysed more;
That of their loues successe they there may make report.
Aie me, how could her loue make half amends therefore.
That he could make; And eeke that angry foole
And make one end of him without ruth or remorse.
That could so meekly make proud hearts auale,
Yet neuer Turtle truer to his make,
And then her eate attonce; or many meales to make.
For sleepe they sayd would make her battill better.
To make a common feast, & feed with gurmandize.
And in this quiet make you safer liue.
He would commend his guift, and make the best.
Were met, to make their sports and merrie glee,
Here leadest in this goodly merry make,
Which here with thee doe make their pleasant playes?
To make them louely or well fauoured show,
To make one minime of thy poore handmayd,
To make it seeme more deare and dainty, as is meet.
Vnto his lust, and make his will his law,
But he himselfe, which did that conquest make;
To make the prises of the rest more deare.
Yet did the cloud make euen that dimmed light
But fortune now the victors meed did make;
Had reft from Meliboe, and from his make,
And gentle pangues, with which he maked meeke
There many Minstrales maken melody,
They do impart, ne maken memorie
The maker selfe for all his wondrous witt,
What had th'eternall Maker need of thee,
His maker with her charmes had framed him so well.
Such as the maker selfe could best by art deuize.
The maker selfe resembling in her feature?
As their Almightie maker first ordained,
All in the powre of their great Maker lie:
Full of the makers guile, with vsage sly
As th'Idole of her makers great magnificence.
Kindled aboue at th'heauenly makers light,
O who can tell the prayses of that makers might!
In goodly measure, by their Makers might,
That makes them doubt, their wits be not their owne:
Faire seemely pleasaunce each to other makes,
And makes the Lyon mylde,
To her makes present of his seruice seene:
But to the easterne coast of heauen makes speedy way.
Through mirkesome aire her readie way she makes.
Far off he wonders, what them makes so glad,
That makes fraile flesh to feare the bitter waue?
Paine, hunger, cold, that makes the hart to quake;
And deadly food he makes: him to offend
Mournes inwardly, and makes to himselfe mone:
Wherewith she makes her louers drunken mad,
And makes it seruant to her basest part:
Weake she makes stro[n]g & stro[n]g thing does increace,
Loue that two harts makes one, makes eke one will:
Loue that two harts makes one, makes eke one will:
And rash Occasion makes vnquiet life.
And great disparagment makes to his former might.
Gainst which the second troupe dessignment makes;
The griesly Wasserman, that makes his game
Through guilefull semblaunts, which he makes vs see.
Makes for him endlesse mone, and euermore
So dischord oft in Musick makes the sweeter lay.
That heales vp one and makes another wound:
Iust cause of dread, that makes ye doubt so sore?
The priuie guilt whereof makes him alway
Makes the huge element against her kind
And makes ensample of mans wretched state,
Smart daunts not mighty harts, but makes them more to swell.
And makes it seeme to haue some other sourse:
Satyrane makes a Turneyment
There he amongst them cruell hauocke makes;
Hath doen to noble knights, that many makes him dread.
And through the thickest makes her nighest waies;
And makes her feare a spur to hast her flight:
That rules the Seas, and makes them rise or fall;
That makes me feare in time he will vs quite forsake.
And makes them like himselfe in glorious sight,
That makes all men for feare that passage for to shonne.
But he him makes his passage-penny pay:
And makes them subiect to his mighty wrong;
And makes wrong doers iustice to deride,
But makes his God of his vngodly pelfe,
That makes the wals to stagger with astonishment:
That weakens her, and makes her party strong:
And makes her ribs to cracke, as they were torne,
And vexeth so, that makes her eat her gall.
And of her owne foule entrayles makes her meat;
Breakes forth, and makes his way more violent.
He makes him Squire, and of him learnes
And makes exceeding mone, when he does thinke
Of whom he makes such hauocke and such hew,
Of that sunne-shine, that makes them looke askew.
And makes huge hauocke, whiles the candlelight
And she coy lookes: so dainty they say maketh derth.
In stoutest minds, and maketh monstrous warre;
He maketh warre, he maketh peace againe,
He maketh warre, he maketh peace againe,
Might looke, that maketh euery creature glad,
And maketh him his wing in vaine to spend;
Of litle much, of foes she maketh frends,
With iron bit, and maketh him abide,
He maketh Kings to sit in souerainty;
He maketh subiects to their powre obay;
It is the mynd, that maketh good or ill,
That maketh wretch or happie, rich or poore:
Making her death their life, and eke her hurt their good.
He making speedy way through spersed ayre,
And at his haughtie helmet making mark,
Making obeyssance, did the cause declare,
Through widest ayre making his ydle way,
The fierce threeforked engin making way,
Wringing her hands, and making piteous mone;
Making sweet solace to her selfe alone;
About her litle frigot, therein making way.
Making aduantage, to reuenge their spight,
Who making vantage of their ciuill iarre,
Where many Mermayds haunt, making false melodies.
Now making girlonds of each flowre that grew,
Making her seeke an vnknowne Paramoure,
At last through wrath and vengeaunce making way,
Now making layes of loue and louers paine,
Of Minstrals, making goodly meriment,
That making way vnto his dearest life,
Where making ioyous feast theire daies they spent
To seeke her lou'd, making blind Loue her guide.
And drew thereto, making her eare her guide.
The first, the gentle Shure that making way
And making all her Knights and people to doe so.
Oft making offer him to smite, but found
All full of people making troublous din,
Making great feast and ioyous merriment,
With bils and glayues making a dreadfull luster;
Weeping to him in vaine, and making piteous woe.
And sought, by making signes, him to asswage:
Of stealth and spoile, and making nightly rode
Full merrily, and making gladfull glee,
But making way for death at large to walke:
Yet making many a borde, and many a bay,
So mak'st thou kings, & gaynest wrongfull gouernement.
That mak'st thy selfe his dayes-man, to prolong
To ioylesse dread, and mak'st the louing hart
The raging seas, and makst the stormes to flie;
Was raced out, and Mal was now put in.
Like to the Mores of Malaber he wore;
His foolish maladie, and long time had misled.
And will to none her maladie impart?
She saw could ease his rankling maladie,
Ne weene what mister maladie it is,
But that it was some other maladie,
The cause of her conceiued maladie,
To feede the humour of her maladie;
From your owne will, to cure your maladie.
There were full many moe like maladies,
Of their sore maladies:
By which he grew to grieuous malady;
And with streight diet tame his stubborne malady.
So still his Malady the more increast,
That in short space their malady was ceast,
Mourning the rigour of her malady,
Malbecco will no straunge knights host,
Malbecco he, and Hellenore she hight,
Malbecco seeing them resolu'd in deed
Then they Malbecco prayd of curtesy,
Malbecco her pursewes:
When chaunst Malbecco busie be elsewhere,
Malbecco seeing, how his losse did lye,
Whom such when as Malbecco spyed clere,
That much Malbecco ioyed in his iollity.
That shortly she Malbecco has forgot,
Where those two guilers with Malbecco were:
Perdy nay (said Malbecco) shall ye not:
Malbecco stopt in great astonishment,
Which when Malbecco saw, out of his bush
Her old Malbecco, which did her vpbrayd,
By their faire handling, put into Malbeccoes cape.
That he Malbeccoes halfen eye did wyle,
That counsell pleased not Malbeccoes mind;
Forth ryding from Malbeccoes hostlesse hous,
And yeelded leaue, how euer malcontent
Ten thousand kindes of creatures, partly male
Ne plate, ne male could ward so mighty throwes,
But had no issue male him to succeed,
But wanting issew male, his daughter deare
Both male and female, both vnder one name:
And all the while faire Malecasta bent
Faire Malecasta, whose engrieued spright
Duessaes traines and Malecastaes
But Huddibras, more like a Malecontent,
Calidore saues from Maleffort,
Cald Maleffort, a man of mickle might,
Maleger doth deface.
Maleger was his name, and after him,
One of Malegers cursed darts did take,
Therefore by name Malengin they him call,
Of such malengine and fine forgerie,
So now Malfont was plainely to be red;
But his sonne Malgo shall full mightily
Simple in shew, and voyde of malice bad,
Halfe mad through malice, and reuenging will,
As when two Bores with rancling malice met,
With cruell malice and strong tyranny:
In poyson and in bloud, of malice and despight.
Of malice in the calme of pleasant womankind.
Now all attonce their malice forth do poure;
With greedie malice and importune toyle,
When not for malice and contentious crimes,
And all the while their malice they did whet
Ne euer pittie may relent his malice hard.
That her sweet loue his malice mote auoyd,
Yet was soone wonne his malice to relent,
So much her malice did her might surpas,
So mortall was their malice and so sore,
The furious flames of malice to asswage.
From inward parts, with cancred malice lind,
But euermore their malice did augment;
Such mortall malice, wonder was to see
And th'other eke his malice did empeach,
With inward griefe and malice did against them swell.
The malice of her foes, which her enuy,
To keepe out guyle, and malice, and despight,
The which with mortall malice him pursu'd so nere.
That all in spight and malice did agree,
Did nought regard his malice nor his powre,
His former malice to some new assay,
Yet he of malice, without her desarts,
In cancred malice and reuengefull spright.
Simple and true from couert malice free:
Till fortune fraught with malice, blinde, and brute,
From malicing, or grudging his good houre,
And next to him malicious Enuie rode,
And forth he fares full of malicious mind,
Of fell reuenge, in their malicious mood
That she could forge in her malicious head,
As bent to some malicious enterprise,
Into the life of his malignant foe;
And my short blisse maligne, yet mote they well
That euen th'Almightie selfe she did maligne,
Mongst many which maligne her happy state,
Though many foes did him maligne therefore,
For to maligne, t'enuie, t'vse shifting slight,
Could not maligne him, but commend him needs:
They enuie her in their malitious mind,
By subtile engins and malitious slight
Had so enranckled her malitious hart,
And seruing her in her malitious vse,
Voide of malitious mind, or foule offence.
Yet in his mind malitious and ingrate
Let driue at him with so malitious mynd,
Vnwares surprised, and with mightie mall
Vpon his headpeece with his yron mall;
And lighting on his horses head, him quite did mall.
To mitigate his stubborne mallady:
In him bewraid great grudge and maltalent:
Cald Maluen, who entrance none denide:
Guyon findes Mammon in a delue,
Great Mammon, greatest god below the skye,
Mammon (said he) thy godheades vaunt is vaine,
Then Mammon wexing wroth, And why then, said,
So soone as Mammon there arriu'd, the dore
Then Mammon turning to that warriour, said;
But whenas Mammon saw his purpose mist,
Mammon was much displeasd, yet no'te he chuse,
Till Mammon did his hasty hand withhold,
Him Mammon answered; That goodly one,
Gramercy Mammon (said the gentle knight)
Mammon emmoued was with inward wrath;
Ne Mammon would there let him long remaine,
For thy great Mammon fairely he besought,
Where Mammon earst did sunne his threasury:
In Mammons house, the Palmer, whom whyleare
Lo I the man, whose Muse whilome did maske,
A monster vile, whom God and man does hate:
God helpe the man so wrapt in Errours endlesse traine.
Such vgly monstrous shapes elswhere may no man reed.
Silly old man, that liues in hidden cell,
Of a straunge man I can you tidings tell,
(Quoth then that aged man;) the way to win
For that old man of pleasing wordes had store,
A bold bad man, that dar'd to call by name
With sword in hand, and with the old man went;
He was, and cared not for God or man a point.
But once a man Fradubio, now a tree,
Wretched man, wretched tree; whose nature weake,
Say on Fradubio then, or man, or tree,
Then womans shape man would beleeue to bee.
For the old man well knew he, though vntold,
In shape and life more like a monster, then a man.
Vnseemely man to please faire Ladies eye;
Inconstant man, that loued all he saw,
Yet wilfull man he neuer would forecast,
Ne none can wound the man, that does them wield.
The foolish man, that pitties all this while
And he the man that made Sansfoy to fall,
Till scornd of God and man a shamefull death he dide.
A silly man, in simple weedes forworne,
Most sencelesse man he, that himselfe doth hate,
What man so wise, what earthly wit so ware,
The guiltlesse man with guile to entertaine?
Such now he marcheth to this man forlorne,
The righteous man, to make him daily fall?
For to haue slaine the man, that on the ground did lye.
But no man car'd to answere to his crye.
An old old man, with beard as white as snow,
The chearelesse man, whom sorrow did dismay,
In warlike feates th'expertest man aliue,
Ne liuing man like words did euer heare,
Yf liuing man mote worthy be, to be her liefe.
A man of hell, that cals himselfe Despaire:
How may a man (said he) with idle speach
That cursed man, low sitting on the ground,
Thee, foolish man, so rash a doome to giue?
None else to death this man despayring driue,
Most enuious man, that grieues at neighbours good,
Ne may a man prolong, nor shorten it;
Thou wretched man, of death hast greatest need,
Why then doest thou, O man of sin, desire
What man is he, that boasts of fleshly might,
Ne let the man ascribe it to his skill,
That weaker wit of man could neuer reach,
The man that would not liue, but earst lay at deathes dore.
O man haue mind of that last bitter throw;
Wherein an aged holy man did lye,
Great grace that old man to him giuen had;
Thrise happy man, said then the father graue,
Then come thou man of earth, and see the way,
Such one, as that same mighty man of God,
Cannot describe, nor wit of man can tell;
Most trew, then said the holy aged man;
That I this man of God his godly armes may blaze.
With his long tayle, that horse and man to ground did rush.
Both horse and man vp lightly rose againe,
Snatcht vp both horse & man, to beare them quite away.
That neuer man such mischiefes did torment;
Much was the man encombred with his hold,
To see the face of that victorious man:
For neuer liuing man, I weene, so sore
Came running in, much like a man dismaid,
The falsest man aliue; who tries shall find no lesse.
Thrise happy man the knight himselfe did hold,
But let that man with better sence aduize,
Yet all these were, when no man did them know;
Why then should witlesse man so much misweene
I read the man, that euer would deceaue
That short reuenge the man may ouertake,
Heare then, ï¿½ man, the sorrowes that vneath
Thrise happie man, who fares them both atweene:
Was hight Sir Huddibras, an hardy man;
The seely man seeing him ryde so rancke,
Trompart fit man for Braggadocchio,
Vaine-glorious man, when fluttring wind does blow
Thus said; Old man, great sure shalbe thy meed,
Is not enough foure quarters of a man,
The man was much abashed at his boast;
Ne can the man, that moulds in idle cell,
But that the foolish man, fild with delight
A mad man, or that feigned mad to bee,
And sure he was a man of mickle might,
Whom that mad man of life nigh late depriu'd,
Faire Sir (quoth he) what man can shun the hap,
The man most warie in her whelming lap.
O wretched man, that would abuse so gentle Dame.
Most ioyous man, on whom the shining Sunne,
This gracelesse man for furtherance of his guile,
Till this mad man, whom your victorious might
Then gan the Palmer thus, most wretched man,
Both horse and man nigh able for to choke;
Was neuer man, who most conquestes atchieu'd
To rid a wretched man from hands of hellish wight.
He was a man of rare redoubted might,
The man awoke, and would haue questiond more;
Vaine man (said she) that wouldest be reckoned
